ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY ACTION POLICIES

Blythe Energy Center is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety, which is evident by Cal-OSHAs designation of the facility as a California Voluntary Protection Program (VPP) Star Site.

The facilitys commitment to safety is also reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that is implemented for both regulated processes on-site.  This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with both ammonia processes at the Blythe Energy Center facility.

It is the policy of Blythe Energy Center to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  If such a release does occur, all facility personnel are trained to assess and mitigate the effects of the release, and to evacuate to safe locations as appropriate.  The facility has coordinated emergency response policies and protocols with the Riverside County Fire Department & Cal-Fire, who can provide additional emergency response support.

Blythe Energy Center employees conduct ongoing inspections, testing, and repairs of the critical items in the ammonia refrigeration system and the aqueous ammonia SCR DeNOx system.  Both systems are inspected on a daily basis, and continuously monitored by a fully trained plant operator stationed in the Control Room.  A record of the inspections and maintenance work performed on each system is maintained electronically on-site.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Blythe Energy Center facility is located at 385 N. Buck Boulevard, in Blythe, California.  The facility is approximately 0.6 miles north of Interstate 10 and 1.6 miles west of California Highway 78.  The area surrounding the Blythe Energy Center facility is rural with few commercial businesses surrounding the facility. 

The regulated substances of concern at the Blythe Energy Center facility are anhydrous ammonia and aque

ous ammonia (29% solution).  Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in a closed-loop refrigeration system that chills the air intake of the combustion turbine electrical generators, thereby increasing their efficiency.  Aqueous ammonia (29% solution) is used in the Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) DeNOx system to reduce the NOx emission in the exhaust gas stream.  The maximum intended inventory of anhydrous ammonia is 55,000 pounds, and of 29% aqueous ammonia is 121,000 pounds (16,000 gallons).  

Anhydrous Ammonia Chiller Refrigeration System:

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously.  The compressors and condensers cycle on and off to comply with system demand during operation.  A majority of the system equipment is located in the Ammonia Chiller Compressor Room.  The Condensers and the  Relief Valve Water Diffusion Tank are located outside the Chiller Compressor Room.

The process begins with high pressure liquid ammonia draining from the Evaporative Condensers to the SOC Receiver.  The SOC Receiver maintains a liquid reservoir for oil cooling of the Screw Compressors (5) via a modulating control valve on the outlet to the Flash Receiver.  The control valve is connected to the liquid level in the vessel, and allows excess liquid to flow to the Flash Receiver, where the pressure of the liquid ammonia is dropped.  The ammonia vapor produced by this partial drop in pressure is drawn from the Flash Receiver through the economizer suction port of the Compressors.  Liquid ammonia is fed from the Flash Receiver to the Pump Recirculator package.

The Pump Recirculation Package uses five (5) pumps to transfer the liquid ammonia to the Combustion Turbine Inlet Chilling System.  Two pumps feed each of the two Chillers, while the fifth pump is included for redundancy purposes.  At the Chillers, liquid ammonia partially boils as it absorbs heat from the air intake of the combustion turbine.  The resultant liquid/vapor mix returns to the Pu

mp Recirculation Package where the remaining liquid is recycled and the Compressors pull the vapor from the top of the vessel.

The main work for the system is conducted by the five Compressors.  Each Compressor draws main suction (ammonia vapor) from the Pump Recirculation Package and economizer suction from the Flash Receiver.  Liquid injection oil cooling is provided by the SOC Receiver, and all Compressors discharge high pressure vapor to the Condensers which are located outside the Chiller Compressor Room.  The Evaporative Condensers reject latent heat from the high pressure ammonia vapor discharged from the compressors to the atmosphere, resulting in a phase change to high pressure liquid ammonia.  Sprayed water and air circulation by fans assists in the evaporative condensing process.  The resulting high pressure ammonia liquid drains to the SOC Receiver in the Chiller Compressor Room.

An automatic purger periodically purges the system of non-condensible gasses (i.e., air) collected in the condensers (high point of the system) to ensure continued safety and efficiency.

Aqueous Ammonia (29.5%) SCR DeNOx System:

The Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system is located outdoors on the property of Blythe Energy Center.  The facility uses 29% aqueous ammonia for Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) to catalytically reduce boiler flue gas nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions to elemental nitrogen and water.  Liquid (aqueous) ammonia is delivered by truck to the facility, and is stored in a double-walled tank which is located in a concrete berm containment area outside, to the west of the most southern heat recovery steam generator (HRSG).

The 29% aqueous ammonia is stored in a ~16,000 gallon double walled tank (Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank) inside a concrete berm containment area located outdoors.  The two pumps are also situated inside the concrete containment berm.  The maximum intended inventory of aqueous ammonia is 121,000 pounds.  The Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank is equi

pped with a level column for local level indication, two pumps, and a single pressure relief valve that also serves as a vacuum breaker (enables laminar flow of ammonia from the tank).

The aqueous ammonia is drawn from the storage tank via feed pumps and underground piping to the ammonia delivery skids (HRSG 11 and 12) mounted at ground level in the power block to a regulating valve which adjusts the ammonia flow based on the NOx readout.  There are two SCR skids and two heat recovery steam generators (HRSG) at the facility, one SCR skid per HRSG.  Each skid contains three flow circuits for the mixing of hot flue gas, aqueous ammonia, and compressed air.  A vaporizer is located at the confluence of the three flow circuits.  On-skid piping includes a duplex Y-strainer, a flow control valve, and a block valve.

The 29% Aqueous Ammonia storage tank also supplies the Boiler pH Control Tote with ammonia via a connection point at HRSG 12 SCR Skid.  Manual operation of the valves is required for the batch fill process.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Blythe Energy Center ammonia refrigeration system and Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system have many safety features.  Much of the safety of the systems is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the systems.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with EPA Risk Management Program (RMP), Cal-OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  These prevention programs cover those processes that handle anhydrous ammonia and aqueous ammonia (29%).

The facility is manned with trained staff 24 hours per day, 7 days per week.  Operators visually inspect the system twice a day during plant rounds, in addition to continuous monitoring of system parameters in the control room.  A preventative maintenance program is in place for both systems to ensure the integrity of the process

equipment is maintained, and risks associated with handling each chemical are minimized.

Anhydrous Ammonia Chiller Refrigeration System:

It is important to note that the ammonia refrigeration system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of ammonia. For example, the compressors are equipped with safety mechanisms that will cause the units to shut down if operating conditions exceed designated safety limits.  Also, level indicators, alarms, and switches are installed in key points within the system to monitor the supply of liquid ammonia and to ensure that a vessel is not overfilled.  The system also incorporates a pressure relief line.  In the event of over-pressurization, vessels will vent through pressure relief valves to a common header which relieves to an atmospheric water diffusion tank (Relief Valve Water Tank) until the system pressure decreases sufficiently to reseat the valves.  This mechanism prevents vessels from rupturing in case they become over pressurized.

Ammonia vapor leak detectors are strategically located in the Chiller Compressor Room, in the inlet to the turbine, in the relief vent line to the Relief Valve Water Tank, and in the vicinity of the chiller coils.  The ammonia leak detectors installed in the Chiller Compressor Room and those located in the vicinity of the chiller coils will initiate the appropriate actions based on the following concentrations:

-25 ppm:  Activates the local alarm in the Control Room, the emergency ventilation fan, and the exhaust treatment water pump.  Alarm annunciators are activated throughout the facility.
-250 ppm:  High level ppm alarm to Control Room.
-10,000 ppm:  Compressors shut down.
-20,000 ppm:  Emergency Mode will de-energize all electrical equipment in the Chiller Compressor Room (with the exception of the emergency ventilation fan and exhaust water treatment) thereby eliminating the potential for an explosion.

The ammonia detector located in the inlet to

the turbine will activate the audible and visual alarm at 25 ppm to notify operators of a leak in the Chiller and shut down compressors after 30 seconds at 250 ppm.  The sensor located in the relief vent will trigger an alarm at 0.5% - 1.0% (5,000 ppm - 10,000 ppm) to notify operators that a relief valve has vented.

There are also three Emergency "Kill" switches which can be activated to shut off the electrical power, start the emergency ventilation, and shut down the emergency compressor pump.  Each switch is located outside next to each entry/exit door of the Chiller Compressor Room. 

In the event of a power failure, ammonia operations would automatically shut-down (solenoid valves close, compressors shut-down, condenser fans and water pumps shut-down, etc.).  Once power is restored, the anhydrous ammonia Chiller Refrigeration System can be restarted from the Control Room.

Aqueous Ammonia (29.5%) SCR DeNOx System:

The Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system at Blythe Energy Center is designed with many safety features.  Much of the safety of the process is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the process.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and the EPA's Risk Management Program (Level 2).  

The 29% aqueous ammonia is stored in a ~16,000 gallon double walled tank (Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank) inside a concrete berm containment area, which is located outdoors.  Along with the Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank, the pump skid is also situated inside the concrete containment berm.  The Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank is equipped with a vacuum breaker to equalize pressures with ambient as needed.  The Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank is also equipped with a single pressure relief valve to relieve pressure should an over-pressurization event occur.

There are "low level", high NOx level, and ammonia slip alarms which alert operators in the Control Room of system mishaps.

A low level alarm is activated when the tank level is at 30% and a message is displayed on the Alarm Sequence Display screen in the Control Room to alert operator to order more aqueous ammonia.  The feed pumps are shut down at approximately 10% and the low level alarm is activated in the Control Room.  A high NOx level will trigger an alarm in the Control Room to alert the operator of a high NOx level at the stack output.  The ammonia slip alarm alerts operators in the Control Room of a high ammonia concentration at the stack output.  

The Emergency Stop button is located near the Aqueous Ammonia Storage Tank containment berm.  Activating the Emergency Stop button shuts down the feed pumps.  The feed pumps can also be shut down remotely from the Control Room.  The Emergency Stop button is activated if the SCR inlet temperature, hot flue gas flow rate, hot flue gas pressure, vaporizer outlet temperature or atomizing air pressure drops below normal operating levels.

The system is also equipped with two leak detectors located underground, one for each SCR skid.  The ammonia leak detectors will alert the Control Room Operator of a liquid ammonia detection.


FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Anhydrous Ammonia Chiller Refrigeration System:

The EPA's RMP Program defines "accident" as the following:

"An unanticipated emission of a regulated substance or other extremely hazardous substance into the ambient air from a stationary source."

The release must have caused at least one of the following:
   --  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or
   --  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place."

Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history, there have been no anhydrous ammonia releases that resulted in injuries, deaths, or significant property damage; or any known off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or shelt

ering in place.

However, the facility did experience an ammonia release during an ammonia transfer operation in preparation for maintenance activities in January 2020.  The release was due to the failure of a one-inch ammonia transfer hose connected to the high side of a compressor pump.  A contracted ammonia transfer truck was on-site to assist in preparing for a turnaround (maintenance outage) and had connected the hose to the Blythe Energy Centers ammonia refrigeration system.  No injuries were sustained  medical personnel cleared all involved.  Emergency notifications were made to the appropriate agencies including California Office of Emergency Services (Cal-OES), Riverside County Environmental Health CUPA, Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District, and the National Response Center.  A full and detailed investigation of the incident was conducted by AltaGas with copies of the report submitted to the appropriate agencies.

Aqueous Ammonia (29.5%) SCR DeNOx System:

Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history, there have been no significant releases of aqueous ammonia that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 1000 pounds of aqueous ammonia or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the past five years.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an aqueous ammonia release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (Plan) in effect.  The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.

Blythe Energy Center personnel routinely circulate throughout the plant,

taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the anhydrous ammonia system twice daily and the Aqueous Ammonia SCR DeNOx system daily.  In case of ammonia detection, visible and audible alarms will activate at the facility and notify the Control Room Operator, who will then initiate the Emergency Action Plan procedures.  It is the policy of Blythe Energy Center to evacuate facility personnel upon alarm.  There are annunciators located inside and outside the building (horns, strobes, etc.).

Once the annunciator is triggered, the Control Room Operator will send a dispatch team to perform an odor investigation.  The dispatch team dons respirator masks and carries a handheld ammonia detector prior to entering the Engine Room when the concentration is between 0 ppm - 250 ppm.  If the concentration is greater than 250 ppm or if there is a white cloud, everyone must evacuate from the building.

Facility calls the fire department and the HAZMAT team to respond in the event of an emergency.  Riverside County Fire Department and/or Cal-Fire will act as the primary Incident Commanders and emergency response team.  In the case of an ammonia-related emergency, it is the policy of Blythe Energy Center to evacuate all employees and to allow the fire department to respond to the emergency (potentially with the assistance of trained facility personnel).

See Blythe Energy Center's Environmental Emergency Response/Action Plan for a detailed explanation of the Emergency Action policies and procedures in effect at Blythe Energy Center.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Blythe Energy Center implements the engineering risk management hazard evaluations for both the anhydrous ammonia chiller refrigeration system, as well as the aqueous ammonia SCR DeNOx process on a 5 year frequency.  Most recently, these studies were conducted in June 2020, both of which resulted in mitigation measures to enhance safety and minimize risks associated with the ongoing operations of the regul

ated processes.  Blythe Energy Center tracks the status of each recommended corrective action to ensure they are completed in a timely manner.

Blythe Energy Center also plans to improve safety as follows:
 
--  Continued involvement of plant operators in the development and implementation of the risk management policies.
--  Implementation of personal qualification package (PQP) to ensure that all plant operators are knowledgeable in the ammonia refrigeration chiller system, as well as the aqueous ammonia SCR DeNOx system, including appropriate safety controls.
--  Continued participation in Cal-OSHAs VPP Star program that requires routine reviews, updates, and corrections.
--  Conducting routine RMP and PSM meetings to ensure any issues identified by plant personnel, ammonia related contractors, consultants, and/or safety department representatives, are discussed and addressed.
